abstract.t: This document defines a new External BGP (EBGP) peering type known as BGP-OAD. BGP-OAD peering is used between two EBGP peers that are part of the same One Administrative Domain (OAD).

section.name: Introduction
section.t: At each EBGP boundary, BGP path attributes are modified as per standard BGP rules . This includes prepending the AS_PATH attribute with the autonomous-system number of the BGP speaker and stripping any IBGP-only attibutes.

Some networks span more than one autonomous sytem and require more flexibility in the propagation of path attributes. These networks are said to belong to One Administrative Domain (OAD). It is desiable to carry IBGP attributes across EBGP peering when the peers are part on OAD. This document defines a new EBGP peering type known as BGP-OAD. BGP-OAD peering is used between two EBGP peers that are part of the same OAD. This document also defines rules for route announcement and processing for EBGP-OAD peers.

ol.li: EBGP-OAD used by two External BGP peers that are part of a same OAD

section.t: The EBGP-OAD speaker has a BGP connection between two external peers in different Autonomous Systems that are part of a same OAD. These EBGP-OAD speakers follow the route advertisement, route processing, EBGP path attribute announcement and EBGP path attribute processing rules of the EBGP speakers as defined in . However, the extensions defined in this document also allow EBGP-OAD speakers to announce and receive any IBGP-only attributes that were restricted to remain within an Autonomous System .

The only IBGP feature extension that is not permitted across EBGP-OAD peers and is outside the scope of this document is the support for the Confederations . Both the AS_CONFED_SEQUENCE and AS_CONFED_SET MUST NOT be used by members of an OAD.

Unless explicitly specified, all path attributes MAY be advertised over an EBGP-OAD session. The reception of any path atrribute over an EBGP-OAD session MUST NOT result in an error, unless it is malformed. It SHOULD NOT be ignored by the receiver, unless directed to by local policy.

Unless explicitly specified, the modification of path attributes sent through an EBGP session remains unchanged when advertised through an EBGP-OAD peering. For example, the AS_PATH is modified as specified in .
The following sections describe modifications to route advertisements and path attribute announcements that are specific to the EBGP-OAD peering.

section.name: Nexthop Handling
section.t: It is reasonable for EBGP-OAD peers to share a common Interior Gateway Protocol (IGP). In such a case, NEXT_HOP attribute and the Next Hop in the MP_REACH_NLRI attribute MAY be left unchanged.

section.name: MULTI_EXIT_DISC (MED) Handling
section.t:
The determination of the neighboring AS for the purpose of BGP Route Selection MAY also consider the ASN of the EBGP-OAD peer. If so, all the peers in the receiving ASN MUST be conifigured to use the same criteria.

section.name: Deployment Considerations
section.t: If multiple peerings exist between two autonomous systems in the same OAD, all SHOULD be configued consistently. Improper configuration may result in inconsistent or unexpected forwarding. The inconsistent use of EBGP-OAD sessions is out of scope of this document.
